p: COVID‐19 mRNA vaccines encode the spike protein receptor‐binding domain (RBD) of SARS‐CoV‐2, prompting its expression on host cells to generate an immune response. The production of anti‐RBD antibodies not only protects against infection but may also enhance innate immunity. These antibodies may contribute to exaggerated immune responses, including systemic inflammation. Bergamaschi et al. reported that the second dose of BNT162b2 mRNA vaccine led to a sharp rise in cytokine levels, such as TNF‐α and IL‐6. Other studies have associated COVID‐19 vaccination with autoimmune manifestations and cytokine release syndrome. Together, these findings suggest that vaccination can stimulate various immune pathways, potentially leading to allergic‐like reactions and vaccine‐related pneumonitis.
